question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - I wo;uld like to say my focus was primarily on themes of humanism, identity, and racial capital. Each of these themes are directly connected to one another and approach the idea of the black radical tradition in various ways. For humanism, we spent the course reading Fanon, Robinson, Wilderson and other black intellectual thinkers who are redefining what it means to be and exist outside the concept of being human. This directly leads to our understanding of how this would affect idenity, as if one is not even considered to be human or considered to be lesser than human, their would be a sort of inferiority complex or psychological notion of subjugation that would become instilled in a community. Thus, the ideas surrounding racial capital come into the foray, for in order to further advance the rather insatiable hunger of capitalism and its systems, a form of racial order or hierarchy only benefits profit and labor. This course helped me in connecting some of these ideas effectively and providing thoughtful analysis when bringing together these subjects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned different framing of the Black radical tradition.
I learned insights into black critical theory from a non-US perspective as well as a non-male perspective.
I learned alternative views of capitalism and its effects on people of color.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I developed learning from different perspectives, which was something facilitated early on with our first reading of Jasmine and Stars. Outside of the Orientalist perspective that is sometimes favored in the West, my eyes were completely opened to the complexity and beauty of Iran from its beginning. I developed more close-reading skills, especially when it came to the translated Persian works that we read in Radical Love and Rose Garden. I found that by the end of the class, I could read these, and similar works, more quickly while being able to understand its relevance/meaning in the greater Sufi tradition.

response_text: I think this class was especially stimulating because what we learn in the West about Iran is often not the full story, so I found almost everything I learned in this class to actually prove wrong a lot of the preconceived notions that I had about Iran's history and culture. This made it so I always had lots of questions about the material, which I always came in to class prepared with, in addition to questions posed by the in-class lectures. I also liked that we went in chronological order considering the things we were learning about present-day Iran made sense considering what we had learned about Persian history/culture from the very beginning. I wish that we had a little more organized lecture/Powerpoint introduction to the topics we focused on earlier in the class; I found it really helpful later on when we started talking about the Shah/revolution, and think it could have been effective in portraying earlier themes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was stimulating because of how immersive it was. Getting to study Middle Eastern politics and culture while living in the Arab world was an incomparable experience. I was intellectually stimulated every day by the diverse breadth of readings and experiences we had, from meeting with a former advisor to the King of Morocco to going to the Pyramids of Giza. I thought we really took advantage of learning outside the classroom.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Lo and Schanzer offer very different but complementary approaches, which makes for more work but more insight. Taxing but really rewarding class.

response_text: Professor Lo facilitated learning in class through the use of discussion. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: "I would not recommend this course to future students. While visiting the pyramids was a highlight, the overall experience was stressful and lacked the immersive, enriching quality one would hope for in a study abroad program. The professor was not understanding of students’ well-being, often disregarding exhaustion, illness, or logistical delays, and dismissing concerns with comments like 'you're a Duke student.' His teaching style included frequent irrelevant rants and unsolicited political commentary, which made many students uncomfortable. Additionally, much of the course content felt repetitive and unimpactful — visiting similar sites repeatedly without meaningful academic engagement. Weekend trips were exhausting and rushed, leaving little time to actually take in the experiences. The professor was largely absent outside of class and trips, and offered little personal engagement with students.On top of this, there were unexpected out-of-pocket costs that added up quickly, even for group meals that were supposed to be included. Given the high program cost, this was frustrating. Assignment deadlines were rigid, regardless of student health or circumstances, and there was a clear lack of empathy when students were sick or overwhelmed.Honestly, there’s so much about this program that could be talked about for hours — from the disorganization to the exhausting schedule, to the uncomfortable moments with the professor. If I could do it over, I would choose a different study abroad program that better balances academic rigor with cultural immersion and student well-being. The photos might look nice, but they don’t reflect the reality of the experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The workload is greater than some of the other abroad programs, but it is definitely worth it if you are interested in the topic. Professor Lo is an amazing lecturer and presents ideas in an easily accessable and applicable way. He transformed the way I though about middle eastern politics. I can not thank him enough for the amazing program and course. Definately take the class and program if you can.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. I've learnt, at least the foundations of seven different religions and traditions. They're all very interesting and offer valuable insight on how to approach different aspects of the good life.2. I've learnt to pick and choose more effectively. The seven different traditions and religions offer important lessons on different aspects of life. I agree with some, and disagree with others. For example, I appreciate the pragmatism of Stoicism (I think of myself as stoic to an extent), but some things to me are not indifferents, they're simply bad. I prefer Confucianism's focus on ritual in dealing with loss.3. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, particularly with the jounral entries and the many notes and questions we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class.

Professor Antepuli, who taught us about Islam, was the only one I always wanted to hear more from, because of how engaging of a lecturer he was. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

response_text: The dialogue across various traditions was a sight to see. It allowed me to think critically about various traditions and aspects of life. The course readings are excellent, and the lecturers are wonderful, the course has no choice but to be great.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was incredibly stimulating through the discussions and paper we had to write at the end. The freedom we are given to explore and analyze different traditions and own views on God, death, suffering, and happiness is refreshing. I don't believe the discussions were as stimulating though because they were in such large groups. The days we were split into smaller groups within our discussion groups was when I  would actually meet and talk with people.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the teachers

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some of the lecturers content got a bit repetitive. I also wish there was more of a direct connection between the readings and the presentation. Also I wish there were some differentiated homework assignments besides just question and journal entry.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was so interesting to hear the different opinions in class. Having open conversations helped make these discussions more meaningful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was difficult to focus in the lecture hall. Also, the dialogue group performances at the end were not particularly interesting to watch from other students, I would have preferred more content from the professors.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I enjoyed the dialogue group questions and journal practices. Some lectures could have been more theme-oriented to learn more about each religion

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning more about major religions & traditions —> Thinking about my purpose here. Transforming my worldview & my view of my undergraduate experience—what to prioritize, how to proceed with intentionality. —> Realizing the importance of slowing down & being present.The faculty are incredible. The readings were incredible & helped me reframe the way I thought about how I approached life. Guest speaker conversations (with dinner), especially the one focused on the Israel-Hamas War, really helped me ground reflection into the way I approached politics—it made me realize that religion can't really exist independently of politics, which changed the way I thought about political engagement.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The Transformative Ideas program is amazing, but you would probably find more fulfillment in one of their smaller courses. The retreat is awesome and was one of the highlights of my sophomore year.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course to other students. It is unique and unlike any other!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about religions and traditions I wasn't very familiar with. I feel like I gained a more holistic view of what the "good life" might be. Through lectures with different specialized professors, I learned that each tradition has its own outlook on life and that no one has a clear cut answer to the millions of questions we can pose. More specifically, I learned that Transhumanism is centered around technological advancement, which I was unaware of initially.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: Learning the basics and perspectives of each different tradition was extremely insightful. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The class truly has the power to transform ideas. Hearing from such a diverse group of people, all experts in their fields, allowed me develop my own perspectives over life's biggest questions. The course is a truly one of one experience for sophomores, in this critical time of our lives. The teachings of various traditions allowed me to see the world in a whole different light.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand different points of view and relate with each other to find common ground in thought. In light of several issues concurrently happening around the world, this class was a breath of fresh air that allowed civil conversation organized by the amazing professors. The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. And this class reminded me of how important human interaction and conversation is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The discussion groups were great for facilitation discussion in ways that lectures don't allow. I found community in met group, entirely with people of different faiths and experiences. 
The diversity of the instructors was great, both in their fields but also in their ways of conducting the class. 
Best of all, the discussions between the instructors was fantastic. I loved hearing the students questions and listening to how the instructors found agreement and disagreements within their faiths, and how they dealt with challenging questions that arose. This was an opportunity I think people rarely get.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 8 different lecturers who were each so passionately involved with their respective traditions was genuinely so interesting and engaging every lecture. This method of changing topics every class made it easy to understand distinctions between units and ideas, and kept me invested in the course. I also really enjoyed having a journal and doing journal entries, as they were very personal and helped me reflect on my views in a very informal way. The dialogue group/dialogue performance was also great, as I got to build relationships with my classmates and produce something fun. The final reflective project and retreat were also great. Overall, having such dynamic meetings and assignments made the course really enjoyable.

It provided great insight into how someone with a certain perspective would tackle real issues, the disconnects between traditions, and the overlap between traditions.

response_text: Having lots of different instructors was such an amazing experience and I felt really lucky to hear first hand from so many different people. This aspect of the course made it very engaging and captivating. You are able to learn about something new each week, so there's never an opportunity to be bored.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The various professors engaged in amazing and important discussions that were interactive with questioning allowed at the end.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) how to connect health and humanitarianism to a more religious context 
2) how to conduct ethnographic research based on interviews and analysis
3) how to define and interpret acts that are deemed to be "humanitarianism"

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to develop an understanding of religion and humanitarianism through an anthropological approach. I also learned how to interview others in an ethnographic style. Lastly, I learned more about anthropology's history and anthropological theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing that I learned is the importance of critiquing and not following information blindly. Another thing that I learned is what humanitarianism aid is and how it affects all of us. Also, one thing that I learned is how to conduct a professional interview and analyze it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: thinking about the way different religions think in different time periods, how to interview people, how to collect ethnographic data, class conversations and being able to connect to other people's thoughts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed interviewing skills and learned about ethnographic writing. Also, I learned about the history of humanitarianism and how it interacts with global health and religion (two areas that I had not considered its impacts). Finally, I learned about the importance of critically examining structures and avoiding the usage of the word "inherent" because it takes away from the system's impact and reduces it to the individual (in looking at how "aid economies" manifest in various parts of the world).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
critical consideration of philanthropic organizations/work being done
analysis of the ethics behind charity work
more deeply understanding the intersection between religion and humanitarianism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class I developed my critical thinking skills and learned how to evaluate a specific topics from multiple perspectives. Prior to this class I think I accepted a lot of things for the way that they were, but through this class I've learned to leverage different perspectives and think about one topic in different ways. I also strengthened my reading comprehension skills in interacting with readings before every class and pushing myself to think about them in a high level way in order to be able to contribute/have class discussions be meaningful. I was also able to refine my abilities to write in a concise way because I found that since every class was interesting and full of new thoughts, I had too much to write for each paper and had to condense them down to the most meaningful parts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about humanitarianism, especially unspoken issues, the interview process, which aided my people and communication skills, and time management.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about ways of using ethnography to analyze ways of giving. This included thinking about how other religions might conceptualize giving entirely differently, such as "uncompassionate care." We also learned about humanitarianism more broadly and the way this can intersect with religious beliefs, such as in the case of evangelicals in Uganda. Also, we learned about how different religions handle the ethical questions that arise from power imbalances between givers and receivers, such as the ways in which Liberation Theology emphasized an approach that contextualized inequalities and emphasized rights.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think and engage in a form of rigorous analysis when reading a cultural anthropology paper on a theory framework or case study by engaging deeply with the argument not only in a logical linear fashion following the paper but to also really think through and challenge the presented ideas. I learned how to read the case studies presented in anthropology papers and analyze and and form my own opinion by engaging with them not only on the author's presented term of the paper but through my own and differing viewpoints. I learned how to write a paper that articulated a clear concise flow of logic while gaining a greater appreciation for the many ways tones and nuances can be layered in an argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the ethics and anthropology of humanitarianism, and learned how to discern advanced readings with many allusions to history, culture, and religion. Furthermore, how to engage in the process of an interview, and the challenges of social hierarchies in doing such. Overall I learned very much from the outside readings and assignments of this class, not only in regards to ethics and global affairs, but about various distinct cultures, religions, and histories which I could not gain from a regular global health class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course facilitated deeper thinking about our systems of humanitarian aid and gave me a new set of anthropologic tools by which to examine the world, introducing such terms such as philanthrocapitalism and biopower (which helped shape my program II!) I was also introduced to new philosophies of giving within different religions such as Islam and Shamanism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor always made sure to facilitate a positive learning environment, showing extreme enthusiasm and passion for the class content. The discussion-focused portion of the class allowed me to learn more about the readings and content being discussed, by hearing the opinions and thoughts of both my peers and the professor himself.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like that the class was very discussion-based, as it made me more engaged in the material through conversation. For this reason, I think I would keep participation as a major component of the grading criteria.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this class was very welcoming and accepting. In addition, our professor did a great job of being very open to our feedback. I would keep the layout of the class, it was very straightforward and manageable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It was nice that this class was flexible with deadlines and assignments and this made me more engaged with the assignments that we had because I didn't feel overwhelmed with work. I liked that the class was discussion based because I always thought it was interesting to hear how my classmates interpreted the readings differently, and for a lot of the readings I was sometimes confused on the overall argument, so going over that at the start of class was always really helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Dugan made this class easier because of how easy going and understanding he was throughout the year. His teaching style was easy to follow considering how heavy this class topic can be.  He was an amazing professor throughout the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The environment was very conducive to student discussion. It never felt judgmental and students always brought their own ideas. I think requiring reading responses before class was a good idea because it ensured students had completed the readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Dougan's course was one of the most memorable courses I have had in my time at Duke so far. Professor Dougan was extremely funny and personable during class, and used many analogies and anecdotes to better describe an abstract idea or concept. Professor Dougan was easily able to simplify a paper or many concepts that took me many reads and left me with my head spinning and feeling like there was no point in the paper to bring me to a point of understanding where I felt I could explain it to someone else. He was very kind and respectful, and always took the time to understand our point of view or misunderstandings on a topic to better explain a concept to us. The readings on the course were all very crucial and built up a rigorous foundation for my understanding of religious frameworks of humanitarian aid in a stepwise manner, but also gave differing points of view to allow us to navigate and reconcile conflicting viewpoints for ourselves.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I believe that Pr. Dougan picked the readings very strategically, and that it allowed us to have a very comprehensive overview on the history, modern state, and future of colonialism’s effect on humanitarianism. Furthermore I believe the interview project was a great way to further gain applicability of the more abstract concepts taught in class, and pushed me as a student in personal time management, social skill development, and organization.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because of the fascinating topics, especially concerning ethics and history, that I had not heard of before. It made me consider new viewpoints and developed my worldview immensely.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Something that made this class intellectually stimulating was the reading material along with our class discussions which were often very debated and controversial which kept me questioning, learning, and taking different view points.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We learned about so many different religions, anthropologies, time periods, humanitarian efforts. Overall there was just a lot to learn about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think if we were able to talk more, given that this is a seminar class, rather than listening to the professor talk (which was most classes), that would be very helpful. Also, more videos/movies would help make the class more engaging as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: examining work that is inherently done with vulnerable populations is essential. This class provided an opportunity to engage with this topic in a way that reframes what humanitarianism is, and how religious organizations play a role in that.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings and discussions in this class were what made it stimulating. Both Professor Dougan and the rest of class had really interesting insights and the fact that the whole class was engaged and thinking critically elevated my learning to do the same. I also liked how we connected to modern society and culture because it made the learning more useful and understandable, such as talking about the implications of social media in becoming a source of news and how that it going to impact the way that we are motivated to give/provide aid.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We talked a lot about the effects of humanitarianism, which consisted of topics like colonialism, white saviors, and exploitation. Being able to talk about these topics with a white cis professor was very impactful to the way I handle these conversations, especially because of how receptive he was to the students in the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings covered a broad assortment of topics, and the essay questions definitely encouraged us to consider these topics more deeply. For example, we read about images of suffering and then analyzed a humanitarian image of suffering from a particular religious group. This was very engaging and required deeper intellectual work. We also completed our own interview which was an interesting experience.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, I developed critical understanding of the context and imperatives of East Asian Studies. The question of what it means to be an Asian Asianist allowed me to deeply engage with our reading materials and speakers from various academic and disciplinary backgrounds. Secondly, I developed writing skills on generalizing and discussing about the arguments made by our speakers. Thirdly, I was able to reflect on the possibilities and limitations of my own discipline and at the same time bridging conversation with other disciplines.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've learned a great deal about the "secrets of academia." Professor Chow meticulously introduces disciplines and methodologies by inviting professors from different fields each week, a valuable experience not easily found elsewhere. Through interactions with these professors, I've grasped the subtle nuances between disciplines, topics, academic institutions, and departments. This understanding will be immensely helpful for my future doctoral applications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The history of East Asian Studies; New theories and trends in Asian history;  New theories and trends in Asian literature

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. Professor Ara Wilson's concept of queer regionalism is especially insightful, as it negotiates the dominant Western queer studies with cultural contexts in East Asian society. 2. Professor Qiao's illustrations on the Homeowner Associations in China shows how grassroots organizations not only function hand in hand with the state power but also grant a degree of agency for ordinary people. 3. I've been intrigued by the approach that views Asia as a method instead of the object of study, which stresses cross-regional culture flow and Asia's cultural specificity as a whole.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned about Christopher Columbus and his 4 voyages. I learned about the history revolving this time. I also learned how to think like a historian.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to engage with primary texts, investigating the context and affect behind each text. I opened my eyes and mind to new ways of understanding the machinations of colonization in the Americas. I also learned great background information on the colonization of the Americas generally.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In terms of specifics, I learned about the four voyages of Columbus within the variety of historical and cultural contexts that they took place in.  In the broader sense, I developed abilities for considering and thinking about historical texts.  I was also encouraged throughout the course to focus and work on my own reading habits and time management as a graduate student.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I have been exposed to an entire array of writing and readings that I had never previously encountered, and that is so exciting. The ideas and beliefs that I had upon joining the class in relation to Columbus have further developed and are much more informed. This course has helped my thinking of connected histories and the ways in which we read/write/do history. The contexts that gave birth to Columbus have been very eye-opening and give solid grounds to how a character, as emblematic (in its many definitions) as Columbus, came to be and evolve into what it did. My thinking is certainly more robust when considering Columbus and his contemporaries.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor facilitated conversations about the readings and provided additional knowledge about the subjects that we learned about. I loved it and think he should keep doing that in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the intention behind crafting an interdisciplinary classroom, made possible by crosslisting this course across many departments and opening it to UNC students. I loved studying these historic texts and secondary sources with students outside of my own program, which allowed for new insights and understandings that have shaped the way I approach work in my home discipline. Dr. Martin created a lot of pathways for us to engage with the material, and I appreciated the weekly message board assignment as it allowed for me to engage my classmates and begin a dialogue even before I entered the classroom. This was especially meaningful for a weekly seminar where I only see my classmates once a week, and want to make the most of the time together. Dr. Martin did a great job lightly facilitating the class, but otherwise emphasizing a student-led discussion of the materials. He never discouraged us from pressing a topic or conversation further, even if it didn't directly address the overall seminar topic, and these conversations always ended up being very rich and linking us back to the ideas and concerns that make us interested in studying Columbus in the first place.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I always appreciate seminar style courses.  Hearing the thoughts of my fellow classmates helps me to figure out and puzzle through and at times challenge (in good ways) my own take-aways from weekly readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We read the entirety of The Divine Comedy, as well as the Vita Nuova and some supplements, so I learned quite a bit about Dante himself, as well as the political, theological, and philosophical environment in which he was situated compared to his own ideology. I learned how to analyze different translations of the text side-by-side, how to critique commentaries, and how to find relevant parallels between the different cantica. I also learned how to express all of this in writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to engage with an arduous piece of literature from seven centuries ago, analyzing many political, theological and ethical themes that are relevant for today's world. I learned to read intently and read with purpose, clarifying the poem as I went through and engaging in critical discussions with my peers. Ultimately, my essays allowed me to exercise my knowledge on the poem and deepened my understanding every single time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof Eisner is one of my favorite professors at Duke. He is one of the most knowledgeable Dantean scholars out there, and his enthusiasm about Dante is infectious. His slides are so well-curated and he has so many random fun facts, e.g. about Virgil's pesto recipe on the US dollar bill. I thought the reading assignments were well-paced for the most part. The midterm was mostly fair passage identification and some factual information (expecting the final to be similarly fair). The papers were actually quite fun to write because we could choose to write about any translations, parallels, and commentaries we thought were most intriguing, i.e. there was a lot of free rein. The group activities, like the in-class art project, were great. I enjoyed the guest lecturer as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Martin Eisner elevated my learning experience of Dante's Divine Comedy through his energetic personality and thought-provoking insights into a rather esoteric poem. He elucidated a lot of thoughts I had coming in when I briefly read about 12 cantos. He forced us to grapple with many dimensions of Dante's poem and challenged my many preconceived notions on love, free will, the existence of a soul, and the role of mentorship within life. I would love to keep the whole presence of Professor Eisner within the course as I cannot imagine a more suitable professor to guide us through the dark wood that is the Spring semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dante's Divine Comedy is not just a story about a pilgrim who struggles to reach a heavenly paradise with Virgil as his guide, but rather leverages his writing to put the reader in an oasis chock-full of his own intimate thoughts regarding love, free will, the divinity of God. He is not afraid to step outside orthodox boundaries to go after people he doesn't like. Dante Alighieri freely and frequently brandishes his ire against 14th century ecclesial figures and put them through heart-wrenching methods of suffering. This coupled with an acute sense of self-awareness makes it hard to hate an exiled 14th century Italian man's charisma.

Learning about the three different major monotheistic religions is learning three specific things in and of themselves. Learning about religion in a historical context is one of the most interesting things to learn and I've learned to shift my thinking from a theological prespective to a historical critical one. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the evolution of the three main Abrahamic texts. I learned how scripture is interpreted, who interprets it, and how that has shaped the communities of different religions. I learned how to be a historic critic of religious texts and why that role is ESSENTIAL to understanding society and religion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how scriptures of Islam, Christianity, and Judaism are compiled and interpreted. I also learned about the basic structure of each religious text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Reading scripture as "a book" rather than a religious text
Learned different methods of interpretation
learned the history that led to the evolution of these different interpretations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to look at scriptures from a historical and critical perspective rather than a religious one
I learned about the canonization of each scripture and the complexities behind each
I learned of how each of the religions cope with issues and how they try to modernize

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to distinguish between religion and scripture from a scholarly perspective. We learned different words in Greek, Hebrew, and Arabic. We also learned about different key figures in each religious tradition.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: the structure of choosing a focus and then working through it in each tradition was well laid out (much better than doing the 1st portion strictly on judaism, the middle portion on christianity, and the final portion on islam)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors were very open to answering questions outside of class and were very quick to respond which I appreciated. Each professor was so excited to speak about their areas which was nice to see.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the lectures, they were very stimulating. I also thought the readings were interesting and actually pertinent. I also liked visiting the rare books library and attending the Iftar. More experiences like that during the course or as supplements would be really interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the reading to help facilitate learning in lectures and I also appreciated that we had a guided reflection to fill out about the readings. It held me accountable to do my readings and engage with them. I also just enjoyed the overall structure of the class and how it would shift from each religion and how there would aslo be days where our professors would teach on a common topic. Additional to the structure I enjoyed that there were only two major assignments to do throughout the whole semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings were "good" for the most part. It's definitely the right idea, but sometimes the instructions were vague and the links were hard to find. I would certainly keep these graded readings, and expand on the feedback. The lectures were always excellent and the professors always came OVERLY prepared. It was impressive and refreshing to be taught by professors who had too many slides and could talk for hours on their subject. Don't change a thing about the lectures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors would often give us handouts to follow along easier in class, and they also would pick students to read slides, which was helpful in keeping us engaged. The reading responses  also helped us come into class with a basis of knowledge on the subject that was to be discussed that day.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures themselves were often quite interesting. The humor and style of the presentations were fun as well. The sensitivity and content with which the professors approached religious topics made for a good learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the split lectures and how every class I felt like I was being taught by an expert in the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors took us to the rare book library and used slides, videos, and worksheets to facilitate our learning. The trip to the rare book library was interesting and should be kept because it was super cool to see and have access to those ancient materials (it also gives exposure to the library for those who may not know it exists). The slides helped guide learning as well. The energy of the teachers helped facilitate learning. You can tell that they are enthusiastic about their work and sharing what they have worked on for so long. Their extensive knowledge in their respective subject field was helpful!I appreciated how understanding the professors about turning in assignments late and extenuating circumstances. I also appreciated how much prof mclarney would reach out and affirm me of my work and that I was doing well b/c I was unsure of my performance

response_text: Engage with it the best you can! If you do it could be one of the most interesting and fun classes you'll take in your time at Duke. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about Islamic religion and culture I never knew before, such as how Muslims greatly differed in their style of interpretation of scripture and how their scripture was revealed; I learned about how there is no such thing as a single scripture or a shared belief because religion changes constantly and is constantly interpreted; I learned that each Abrahamic faith has a specific tradition of interpretation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- how complex religion and scripture is

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This has got to be the most interesting class I've ever taken. It was very inteluctally stimulating and I've learned so much. Learning about the three different major monotheistic religions is learning three specific things in and of themselves. Learning about religion in a historical context is one of the most interesting things to learn and I've learned to shift my thinking from a theological prespective to a historical critical one. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the evolution of the three main Abrahamic texts. I learned how scripture is interpreted, who interprets it, and how that has shaped the communities of different religions. I learned how to be a historic critic of religious texts and why that role is ESSENTIAL to understanding society and religion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Reading scripture as "a book" rather than a religious text

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned gow to engage with the structural levels of society with a critical lens. I also improved my skills for navigating difficult texts. Finally, my confidence in my inquiry abilities rose.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a way of thinking through theory that can be applied to real current and historical events, a way of questioning assumptions about how and why societies participate in certain practices, and a way of questioning how implicit and explicit religious practices shape systemic racism and injustice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I entered this class expecting to have a history of religion in the United States, but what I got instead was a rich survey of the ways that religious thinking has informed some of the country's greatest moral failings. I learned about the social, financial, and legal elements of the country that are based in religious thinking and which may or may not be useful today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class allowed me to think about race in a much more meaningful, and new way than in all my previous courses. I enjoyed reading about topics like the military-industrial complex, race, and debt from theory viewpoints before having discussions in class to bring those theories into the everyday and figure out how to make sense of it all for our own lives. I also acquired new modes of interpreting theories and applying them to society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: close reading, critical thinking, respectful discussion, how race fuels inequalities in our society, how money flows through our society in a way analogous to a religion that people worship and give their life purpose with

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The conversational tone of the class was helpful for creating a safe space to discuss hard and complex topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The use of reading and discussion questions as the focus of the course were helpful for keeping me engaged in close reading of texts rather than worried about writing essays. The seminar class style was effective especially with a little bit of background and explaining through the more difficult parts of the text and then getting into discussion questions. I also thought the essay that builds throughout the class was great, because it forced me to start thinking about it early without leaving a lot of work at the end.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very helpful with feedback on assignments leading up to the final paper, which made writing it seem much less daunting. I appreciated the grading structure where we were evaluated on completeness for the building blocks of the final paper (abstract, bibliography, etc) and given useful feedback going into the final paper.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was fairly independent, and then we would meet weekly to discuss key points of readings. I appreciated the space to sit with works on my own before coming to class that way. I also think the weekly reflection questions held us accountable but also helped us yo lead quality discussions with one another.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Very diverse and compelling readings that were connected to each other in nuanced ways. Reviewing the content of the readings and then having class conversations is a great way to learn as much as possible about the topic of each week, having the students write discussion questions each week was a good way to stimulate conversation, engaging with readings and films or videos in class was a good way to create shared experiences of knowledge that could be reflected on as a class which allowed for deeper learning

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

This class did so much to help me understand what it means to live in this country and to grapple with its often dark history.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I came into the class with very little knowledge of the Bible, I would say I learned how to read the Bible in a less biased way and became more aware of the biases that are ingrained in certain biblical interpretations. I also learned about the multitude of ways in which the Bible intersects with society, past and present.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically and with different perspectives about the Bible. Some interesting things I was able to learn include: how to use WordPress, how the Bible impacted slavery and the civil rights movement, and the history and development of the Bible.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the history of the Bible, modern denominations and their biases, and the ways in which the Bible is used in modern politics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Particular focus on removing personal biases in historical study, seeing other people’s perspectives 
Heavy emphasis on broad scope in readings and analysis 
Later focus on presenting information in a professional and accessible way

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how the Bible was created using the documentary hypothesis. We examined how the Bible was used in America in the slavery, abortion, and death penalty debates. I was able to create my own website discussing the Bible on a topic of my choosing guided by Dr. Brettler.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Way of thinking: historical critical perspective of the Bible
Understanding of the flaws of the Bible, different translations, the way different people/religions will emphasize completely different parts of the same passage and gain a completely different meaning. How the Bible impacts American politics and American history. Defining misuse of the Bible. How to construct a website using wordpress, how to find images for a virtual exhibit, how to make a virtual exhibit, how to make a website accessible for others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how there are different Bibles and the implications of this on issues in the U.S.; I learned what makes a good virtual exhibit and how to create my own; and I learned about different biblical perspectives on issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Lastly, I think I was able to develop communcaiton skills through both sharing my thinking in class as well as through the 3 analytical papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Some skills and insights that I developed in this course include critical and analytical thinking, close readings of literature and film, and academic writing. 
1. In film, everything is intentional. While a major aspect of film is entertainment, films are attempt to "say" things. 
2. In order to get at what a film is trying to "say," pay attention to what's there (color, space, storytelling, dialogue, etc.) but, perhaps more importantly, note what is absent. 
3. Films converse between each other all the time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: When reading through the Masnavi/Memorial of God's Friends it may sometimes be helpful to search up references to the Qur'an/figures and events in Islamic history in order to better understand the text. The Masnavi contains a reference in the back that is especially important to look up, since Rumi makes many metaphors and references that those not familiar with aspects of the Islamic faith are likely to miss. Attar is more comprehensible but he is by nature a poet, and so should also be read in this way.Read the texts very carefully.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. I've learnt, at least the foundations of seven different religions and traditions. They're all very interesting and offer valuable insight on how to approach different aspects of the good life.2. I've learnt to pick and choose more effectively. The seven different traditions and religions offer important lessons on different aspects of life. I agree with some, and disagree with others. For example, I appreciate the pragmatism of Stoicism (I think of myself as stoic to an extent), but some things to me are not indifferents, they're simply bad. I prefer Confucianism's focus on ritual in dealing with loss.3. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, particularly with the jounral entries and the many notes and questions we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. The interest I and others would gain from lectures is often overshadowed by the confusion regarding deadlines and grading expectations. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.
