question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The content but it needs more personal engagement

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The dialogue across various traditions was a sight to see. It allowed me to think critically about various traditions and aspects of life. The course readings are excellent, and the lecturers are wonderful, the course has no choice but to be great.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was incredibly stimulating through the discussions and paper we had to write at the end. The freedom we are given to explore and analyze different traditions and own views on God, death, suffering, and happiness is refreshing. I don't believe the discussions were as stimulating though because they were in such large groups. The days we were split into smaller groups within our discussion groups was when I  would actually meet and talk with people.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the teachers

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some of the lecturers content got a bit repetitive. I also wish there was more of a direct connection between the readings and the presentation. Also I wish there were some differentiated homework assignments besides just question and journal entry.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was so interesting to hear the different opinions in class. Having open conversations helped make these discussions more meaningful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was difficult to focus in the lecture hall. Also, the dialogue group performances at the end were not particularly interesting to watch from other students, I would have preferred more content from the professors.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I enjoyed the dialogue group questions and journal practices. Some lectures could have been more theme-oriented to learn more about each religion

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning more about major religions & traditions —> Thinking about my purpose here. Transforming my worldview & my view of my undergraduate experience—what to prioritize, how to proceed with intentionality. —> Realizing the importance of slowing down & being present.The faculty are incredible. The readings were incredible & helped me reframe the way I thought about how I approached life. Guest speaker conversations (with dinner), especially the one focused on the Israel-Hamas War, really helped me ground reflection into the way I approached politics—it made me realize that religion can't really exist independently of politics, which changed the way I thought about political engagement.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The Transformative Ideas program is amazing, but you would probably find more fulfillment in one of their smaller courses. The retreat is awesome and was one of the highlights of my sophomore year.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course to other students. It is unique and unlike any other!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The class truly has the power to transform ideas. Hearing from such a diverse group of people, all experts in their fields, allowed me develop my own perspectives over life's biggest questions. The course is a truly one of one experience for sophomores, in this critical time of our lives. The teachings of various traditions allowed me to see the world in a whole different light.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand different points of view and relate with each other to find common ground in thought. In light of several issues concurrently happening around the world, this class was a breath of fresh air that allowed civil conversation organized by the amazing professors. The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. And this class reminded me of how important human interaction and conversation is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The discussion groups were great for facilitation discussion in ways that lectures don't allow. I found community in met group, entirely with people of different faiths and experiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 8 different lecturers who were each so passionately involved with their respective traditions was genuinely so interesting and engaging every lecture. This method of changing topics every class made it easy to understand distinctions between units and ideas, and kept me invested in the course. I also really enjoyed having a journal and doing journal entries, as they were very personal and helped me reflect on my views in a very informal way. The dialogue group/dialogue performance was also great, as I got to build relationships with my classmates and produce something fun. The final reflective project and retreat were also great. Overall, having such dynamic meetings and assignments made the course really enjoyable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Developed writing and reading skills, especially improved during writing reflection posts throughout the course and the major essays. Also gained new perspectives on historical narratives, sources and interplays of common cultural themes relevant even today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about a broad swath of culture and influences shared between Muslim and Jewish, and sometimes Christian communities. Learned that conflict between Muslim and Jewish communities is not si deeply entrenched in history as one would think from the current state of the world, that much of their culture and intellectual heritage has overlap. Learned about religious government and transition of power, myths of conquest and violence in medieval Spain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is great, it's super interesting and eye opening about many things I knew absolutely nothing about. You don't need any prior knowledge of the topic to take the course. The professor is really nice and class is generally pretty engaging. The class is quite a lot of work, and it certainly isn't easy. You need to do a lot of reading and write a weekly discussion post on the reading, and you have a couple big papers which are tough. But, the professor does provide you with lots of help and resources for those, so the work is manageable for the most part. Overall, I highly recommend this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly rеcommеnd taking this coursе in thе futurе. Thе profеssor is not only undеrstanding and accommodating for studеnts facing challеngеs but also incrеdibly passionatе about thе topic, having dеdicatеd еxtеnsivе timе to its study. Thе еxploration of mеdiеval Spain's history, particularly thе insights into thе thinkеrs of that timе, provеd to bе a captivating journеy. Discovеring thеir idеas and undеrstanding thеir lasting impact on thе prеsеnt addеd a rich layеr to thе coursе, making it both intеllеctually stimulating and pеrsonally fulfilling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of art markets, value systems, and the shady side of art and archaeology. I learned to think more critically in instances of nuance where an argument for one side or another is difficult.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Historical questioning, ethical questioning, research

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about loot as an all-encompassing reality (cultural, historical, and archeological settings as well as aspects of law, colonialism, oppression, war, and money). I also learned how to interpret the provenance and provenience of objects to think critically and deeply about whether it is loot. I also learned how to read complex articles, books, and journals that go into the details of an object's history and present circumstances as well as find provenance of an object who does not have much known provenance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- moral considerations surrounding the ownership of cultural heritage
- evaluation of contested institutions such as museums, archives, and libraries
- (il)legal appropriation of sacred objects

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I knew a bit about looting and provenance as I worked at the nasher reorganizing their provenance files however I didn’t know the legal side of things and this class really introduced me to that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a significant amount of knowledge regarding how to approach provenance research, balance the complexities of repatriation cases, and navigate the challenging duality of legality and ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how art and artifacts have been used as symbols of power and have been stolen throughout history. I also learned about the legal side of culteral protection which I did not know much about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to look at the possession of cultural artifacts critically, how to examine and research the provenance of objects and artifacts, and how the repatriation of cultural artifacts works.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 3 different professors with 3 different areas of expertise was really helpful. We got such a developed view of the issues that way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors worked incredibly hard to facilitate our learning by routinely interjecting lectures to ask the students for active feedback. As such, we were constantly encouraged to participate and reflect on the readings that we did before classes. The occasional in-person outside speaker series were an aspect of the class that I believe should be kept for future years since it was such a delight to have such groundbreaking professionals as Patty Gerstenblith and Morag Kersel speak to our class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More student participation and engagement would have made this course more stimulating. Sometimes, the lectures went on the whole class without much student participation at all, which, no matter how interesting, I find hard to concentrate on. I wish as well there was less coverage on the law and specific dates and times of discovery and more on the rich and complex histories and relationships of the object to place.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel that the class would've been way more intellectually stimulating if the professors had gone a little less into the minutiae of the history of the objects and more into general, ethical discussions about the implications of repatriation concerning the artifact at hand. Moreover, I felt like I needed to take a pre-law course to be adequately prepared for this class since the readings were often so lengthy and confusingly worded that they lost all sense of impact on me as a student and were, by no means, intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course could certainly be rewarding for someone with a deep interest in archaeology, manuscript studies, ancient cultures, and/or divinity studies. That said, I was sorely disappointed by the fact that it often felt more like a pre-law course or prerequisite history class rather than a supposedly fun, interactive course that I intended to take out of passion--a passion that, because of this course, I caught myself having to repeatedly remind myself why I liked this major and wanted to keep pursuing it in the first place.

response_text: You do not need a strong background in art history or religious studies to find the material very interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is the class I loved most at Duke so far. There is a lot of material and it is very fast but once you get used to the reading workload it turns into something very fun. A great way to learn about new things and see history, politics, and religion in a different light.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is focused on Turkey's history, but you will end up learning a great deal beyond that. Will recommend to anyone regardless of what the student's major is.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is hard but totally doable even if you have no background. I was scared at first and considered dropping. It takes 2-3 weeks to really feel like you are getting it but the payoff is awesome. You just need to do all the readings to keep up.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about the intersection between religion and sports and how they both share many similar characteristics such as having idols, rituals, and prayer.
I also learned about how religion has influenced sport - since many top athletes are very religious, the values and practices of particular religions are put on display for many people to see through sport.
Finally, I also learned about the impact that many religious stereotypes can have and how they can be portrayed through sport such as issues with mascots misrepresenting Native Americans.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We read the entirety of The Divine Comedy, as well as the Vita Nuova and some supplements, so I learned quite a bit about Dante himself, as well as the political, theological, and philosophical environment in which he was situated compared to his own ideology. I learned how to analyze different translations of the text side-by-side, how to critique commentaries, and how to find relevant parallels between the different cantica. I also learned how to express all of this in writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to engage with an arduous piece of literature from seven centuries ago, analyzing many political, theological and ethical themes that are relevant for today's world. I learned to read intently and read with purpose, clarifying the poem as I went through and engaging in critical discussions with my peers. Ultimately, my essays allowed me to exercise my knowledge on the poem and deepened my understanding every single time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof Eisner is one of my favorite professors at Duke. He is one of the most knowledgeable Dantean scholars out there, and his enthusiasm about Dante is infectious. His slides are so well-curated and he has so many random fun facts, e.g. about Virgil's pesto recipe on the US dollar bill. I thought the reading assignments were well-paced for the most part. The midterm was mostly fair passage identification and some factual information (expecting the final to be similarly fair). The papers were actually quite fun to write because we could choose to write about any translations, parallels, and commentaries we thought were most intriguing, i.e. there was a lot of free rein. The group activities, like the in-class art project, were great. I enjoyed the guest lecturer as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Martin Eisner elevated my learning experience of Dante's Divine Comedy through his energetic personality and thought-provoking insights into a rather esoteric poem. He elucidated a lot of thoughts I had coming in when I briefly read about 12 cantos. He forced us to grapple with many dimensions of Dante's poem and challenged my many preconceived notions on love, free will, the existence of a soul, and the role of mentorship within life. I would love to keep the whole presence of Professor Eisner within the course as I cannot imagine a more suitable professor to guide us through the dark wood that is the Spring semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dante's Divine Comedy is not just a story about a pilgrim who struggles to reach a heavenly paradise with Virgil as his guide, but rather leverages his writing to put the reader in an oasis chock-full of his own intimate thoughts regarding love, free will, the divinity of God. He is not afraid to step outside orthodox boundaries to go after people he doesn't like. Dante Alighieri freely and frequently brandishes his ire against 14th century ecclesial figures and put them through heart-wrenching methods of suffering. This coupled with an acute sense of self-awareness makes it hard to hate an exiled 14th century Italian man's charisma.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because of the fresh perspective it provided on familiar films. However, in addition to the unclear expectations on assignments, many of the readings were extremely verbose and obfuscated the essential meaning of what they were trying to say--I would have liked some explanation of what each of the sources was trying to get across.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class was an amazing introduction to religion in general and the links drawn between popular films and different religions throughout the world. It really will give you a new perspective, not only when looking at movies, but when analyzing any piece of literature.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr.Coates rocks! Lectures are very engaging and the readings are very manageable. Film screenings are a treat, and class discussions are never dull.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to be involved in the course, because passive participation will lead you to being left in the dust.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the readings and movies and the class discussions we had about them. The movie screenings were really useful to engage with the material and bounce off of other peoples' ideas. The mini-reviews are interesting assignments to apply the knowledge gained over each unit.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked Coates' teaching style - some film clips, some discussion, some lecture. I really liked how we had four in-class film screening days - we watched "The Conjuring," "Star Wars," "God's Not Dead," and "Kumaré." I liked our "mini review" assignments, where you basically produce a 7-minute film review using a class reading from that specific unit and you have to argue why it should be considered religious. The movies and clips we'd watch in class were more obviously religious, so this was a chance for us to get creative and find something that seems secular and apply it to our learnings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The content in the class is really interesting and I liked the group discussions. However, this is not an "easy A" class because the TAs do all of the grading. The TAs grade super harshly and make it really hard to know how to do better in the future, which was really frustrating. Even after asking for feedback and support, they did not help us improve our grades. Also, a huge part of this grade is participation (literally speaking once per every class despite it being a large class) and the final project, which made us really nervous.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class further taught me ways of thinking and viewing the world and to challenge more Western and orientalist narratives, and also to rethink what modernity is and who defines or has defined it. I learned about Iranian poetry, the revolution, and historical relations between the US and Iran and how that has been altered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I learned about the history of Iran

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I developed learning from different perspectives, which was something facilitated early on with our first reading of Jasmine and Stars. Outside of the Orientalist perspective that is sometimes favored in the West, my eyes were completely opened to the complexity and beauty of Iran from its beginning. I developed more close-reading skills, especially when it came to the translated Persian works that we read in Radical Love and Rose Garden. I found that by the end of the class, I could read these, and similar works, more quickly while being able to understand its relevance/meaning in the greater Sufi tradition.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) how to connect health and humanitarianism to a more religious context 
2) how to conduct ethnographic research based on interviews and analysis
3) how to define and interpret acts that are deemed to be "humanitarianism"

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to develop an understanding of religion and humanitarianism through an anthropological approach. I also learned how to interview others in an ethnographic style. Lastly, I learned more about anthropology's history and anthropological theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing that I learned is the importance of critiquing and not following information blindly. Another thing that I learned is what humanitarianism aid is and how it affects all of us. Also, one thing that I learned is how to conduct a professional interview and analyze it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: thinking about the way different religions think in different time periods, how to interview people, how to collect ethnographic data, class conversations and being able to connect to other people's thoughts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed interviewing skills and learned about ethnographic writing. Also, I learned about the history of humanitarianism and how it interacts with global health and religion (two areas that I had not considered its impacts). Finally, I learned about the importance of critically examining structures and avoiding the usage of the word "inherent" because it takes away from the system's impact and reduces it to the individual (in looking at how "aid economies" manifest in various parts of the world).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
critical consideration of philanthropic organizations/work being done
analysis of the ethics behind charity work
more deeply understanding the intersection between religion and humanitarianism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class I developed my critical thinking skills and learned how to evaluate a specific topics from multiple perspectives. Prior to this class I think I accepted a lot of things for the way that they were, but through this class I've learned to leverage different perspectives and think about one topic in different ways. I also strengthened my reading comprehension skills in interacting with readings before every class and pushing myself to think about them in a high level way in order to be able to contribute/have class discussions be meaningful. I was also able to refine my abilities to write in a concise way because I found that since every class was interesting and full of new thoughts, I had too much to write for each paper and had to condense them down to the most meaningful parts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about humanitarianism, especially unspoken issues, the interview process, which aided my people and communication skills, and time management.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about ways of using ethnography to analyze ways of giving. This included thinking about how other religions might conceptualize giving entirely differently, such as "uncompassionate care." We also learned about humanitarianism more broadly and the way this can intersect with religious beliefs, such as in the case of evangelicals in Uganda. Also, we learned about how different religions handle the ethical questions that arise from power imbalances between givers and receivers, such as the ways in which Liberation Theology emphasized an approach that contextualized inequalities and emphasized rights.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think and engage in a form of rigorous analysis when reading a cultural anthropology paper on a theory framework or case study by engaging deeply with the argument not only in a logical linear fashion following the paper but to also really think through and challenge the presented ideas. I learned how to read the case studies presented in anthropology papers and analyze and and form my own opinion by engaging with them not only on the author's presented term of the paper but through my own and differing viewpoints. I learned how to write a paper that articulated a clear concise flow of logic while gaining a greater appreciation for the many ways tones and nuances can be layered in an argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the ethics and anthropology of humanitarianism, and learned how to discern advanced readings with many allusions to history, culture, and religion. Furthermore, how to engage in the process of an interview, and the challenges of social hierarchies in doing such. Overall I learned very much from the outside readings and assignments of this class, not only in regards to ethics and global affairs, but about various distinct cultures, religions, and histories which I could not gain from a regular global health class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course facilitated deeper thinking about our systems of humanitarian aid and gave me a new set of anthropologic tools by which to examine the world, introducing such terms such as philanthrocapitalism and biopower (which helped shape my program II!) I was also introduced to new philosophies of giving within different religions such as Islam and Shamanism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor always made sure to facilitate a positive learning environment, showing extreme enthusiasm and passion for the class content. The discussion-focused portion of the class allowed me to learn more about the readings and content being discussed, by hearing the opinions and thoughts of both my peers and the professor himself.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Dougan's course was one of the most memorable courses I have had in my time at Duke so far. Professor Dougan was extremely funny and personable during class, and used many analogies and anecdotes to better describe an abstract idea or concept. Professor Dougan was easily able to simplify a paper or many concepts that took me many reads and left me with my head spinning and feeling like there was no point in the paper to bring me to a point of understanding where I felt I could explain it to someone else. He was very kind and respectful, and always took the time to understand our point of view or misunderstandings on a topic to better explain a concept to us. The readings on the course were all very crucial and built up a rigorous foundation for my understanding of religious frameworks of humanitarian aid in a stepwise manner, but also gave differing points of view to allow us to navigate and reconcile conflicting viewpoints for ourselves.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I believe that Pr. Dougan picked the readings very strategically, and that it allowed us to have a very comprehensive overview on the history, modern state, and future of colonialism’s effect on humanitarianism. Furthermore I believe the interview project was a great way to further gain applicability of the more abstract concepts taught in class, and pushed me as a student in personal time management, social skill development, and organization.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Analyzing texts and discussing their contemporary reinterpretations also helped develop my critical thinking and interpretative skills. The research papers and presentations honed my research abilities and improved my skills in communicating complex ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned the foundations of Islam, the basics, the structure of it, and the texts that supplement the Quran and Islam grouped by their purposes.
I learned the history of Islam, the controversies surrounding it and its authenticity, and how Islamic scholars have responded to criticisms (external and internal) over time.
I learned how Islam was reinterpreted in modern contexts, particularly in a black empowerment light.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I practiced how to determine credibility of ancient texts and how to gather sources for papers. I learned much about ancient Non-Canonical texts that I was unaware of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I  learned how non-canonical gospels differ from their canonical counterparts and what the significance of the differences is in terms of understanding early Christian beliefs. 
2. I learned how to differentiate between historical/religious documents that are forged and what kind of components to look at.
3. I learned about the relationship between non-canonical gospels and other early Christian texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about several texts I had never heard of before, including the Gospel of Philip, the Gospel of Mary, and several fragmentary gospels. I also developed my skills of putting forth a good academic argument with my midterm and final papers, with the final being significantly more challenging for me. I had to do a lot of research and think hard about how to synthesize it all together into a coherent paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to learn how to recontextualize previously accepted notions. I was able to expand how I think of what history is recorded and remembered, and what is forgotten. It made me remember to search for a whole story and made me want to do further research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the diversity of early Christian thought, the cohesive doctrine of canonical gospels, and about gnostic thought.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to apply comparative analysis skills to Jesus' films to better understand the Gospels and how films are a tool for religious dissemination. I learned how to consider external variables such as responses from religious communities, antisemitism, and cultural shifts to analyze the success of a film. This class contributed to the development of my own faith, as I learned more about Biblical history and the way that Christianity is understood to be true currently.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Overall, learned about how to analyze and have key takeaways from a film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Knowledge: I learned more in-depth about the cultural context of the periods and places seen in the films we watched
Insights: We discussed the more nuanced issues associated with making a Jesus film, including social issues that I generally would not be privy to
Ways of thinking: We focused on looking beyond the film's initial appearance and base intentions to understand the deeper meanings and inclinations not usually noticed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach research and academic writing in the field of religious studies. I also learned new ways of approaching film studies, as we viewed and analyzed films through a combined lens of cinematic and theological analysis. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! It is just the right amount of relaxing and intellectually stimulating. You can be certain that nothing you do is busy work, and I find it hard to imagine that no one would find this course interesting in topic.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is an amazing introduction to not only analyzing film, but also how the stories of Jesus can be best depicted on the big screen. I would highly recommend this course for all those interested in learning how film writers decide to depict stories of the nativity, Jesus' ministry, and the crucifixion. Mark Goodacre has been one of my favorite professors during my time at Duke – he leads class discussions extremely well and has unmatched energy and enthusiasm. If you're looking for an interesting, low-stress, fun class where you watch incredible movies for homework and break them down in class, this is your course!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will give you insight into the gospel stories, the film industry and the history of the middle east and the Roman empire. It does not require any prior gospel, film or historical knowledge and encourages curiosity for anyone who has no previous experience in these areas.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it, even if you're not interested in film, Jesus, or religion. Mark is one of the best professors I have ever had. He is incredibly kind, understanding, and so funny! Genuinely the best ALP I've taken at Duke and Prof Goodacre deserves more recognition. For a STEM major not really invested in religious studies at all, I looked forward to this class every week.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything honestly. My ways of thinking have just changed in general in this course. I am a more flexible thinker and I have never been forced to so genuinely understand something.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Most of the things that I learned in this class that are more broadly applicable are skills involving analyzing recurring narrative styles, themes, motifs, and even the evolution of ideas of a particular author in a variety of genres over the course of decades. More specifically, this class helped me to grow in my ability to both make these connections across many texts by the same author while at the same time not forcing the text to fit into a predetermined mold.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze a text more honestly and with more depth, how to understand the works of Lewis and how they interact with one another, & how to present a paper in tutorial style.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything, amazing class

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Attentive close reading of literature, being able to analyze themes and concepts from fiction/non-fiction alike. Knowing how to effectively read in order to be prepared for a discussion during class. Writing in such a way that uses the text as the main source of argumentation to power a narrative. Writing that incorporates both fiction and non fiction to make one cohesive argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Exposure to theological concepts, reading stamina, concept synthesis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Read books "cover to cover " which is a rarity to get to do in courses at Duke (outside of the English Department perhaps) 
- Deepened my view of topics that C.S. Lewis wrote about such as the Trinity, God's plan for his people, and even theodicy (through Till We Have Faces)
- Defended writing through the tutorial process

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read intentionally, looking for things inside the text that called back to previous readings or class discussions. This course also helped me develop a way to think critically among my peers, who may have disagreed with me, but I was able to discuss with civility and even made friendships that will last beyond the classroom. I also learned how to engage in class discussion by articulating my thoughts clearly and thinking through them before I speak, and it has improved my thinking to encompass more than just the text right in front of me.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor White is incredible. This is the first seminar I have taken at Duke that has genuinely been a seminar. It's not a lecture where we sit in a circle. I had incredibly stimulating conversations with my fellow students and Professor White rarely interjected. The tutorial style of examinations is great. Not a first, though, I cried after my first tutorial, but that was because I did not properly prepare. Once I did, I found the tutorial to be incredibly helpful in making me a better student.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed that this course was based in complete texts rather than just reading excerpts. Having read so many of CS Lewis' works over the course of the semester, I don't feel like there's any way to effectively capture the significance of his works and their nuance by doing excerpts. I loved the discussion intensive format of the course and feel like the discussions helped me to think more deeply about the material and challenged me to think about things in different ways. Towards the end of the semester, we started getting into groups at the beginning of class and were each assigned a chapter or section from the reading to recap for the class. I loved doing this because it helped me to refresh parts that I may have forgotten from earlier in the reading, helped to clarify aspects that may have been confusing, and highlight details that I may have missed. I also really enjoyed the exam format for this course (Writing an essay, reading the essay to the professor, then discussing the paper). I think this helped to strengthen my writing abilities and my ability communicate complex topics, themes, and ideas in a clear and concise way. While the following statement may not be very popular, I liked the fact that this class was technology free except for writing our papers. I feel like this helped me to be more present in class. The lack of presentation style was personally helpful to me because I often get bogged down by professor's presentations and sometimes distracted by the presentation itself.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. White was absolutely amazing and I am genuinely upset that no one else will get to experience this class the way my classmates and I were able to this year. He is an amazing teacher. The material was also extremely interesting. A class on the works of C.S. Lewis should definitely be permanent. Dr. White structured the course so that there was not an absurd amount of testing done (only 4 main assignments). He was very clear about expectations and was always there to meet and discuss the content. He allowed us to lead the discussion often which made our conversations very enjoyable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes the facilitation by prof white and the engaging tasks such as our debate on till we have faces

response_text: Dr. Nicholas Lee White was the best professor I have had at Duke, he would encourage discussion by opening up with summaries or questions and guiding the seminar to come to our own conclusions on the piece of reading presented to us. I like the tutorial style of evaluation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor White was very intentional about letting us decide our topics of conversation in class, which I felt allowed us to flesh out the things we really wanted to discuss. I think this was good since many of the larger thematic questions were ones that all of us had anyway, but we were also allowed to speak about our personal takes on Lewis' arguments. Professor White was also extremely knowledgeable about the texts and was able to point us to specific page numbers and quotes that allowed us to grasp things more easily and concretely.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I've had several reading intensive courses at Duke and several discussion heavy/seminar style classes but truly feel that this is one of the classes where I found both the reading to be intellectually stimulating as well as the discussions. I don't know how else to put the following but I truly feel like this class helped me to grow in my ability to think deeply about things. I've always been a highly reflective, analytical person but I feel like this class really helped me to grow in this regard.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The reading of C.S. Lewis made it incredibly stimulating, we explored complex theological subjects on the purpose of life itself and Christian doctrine, both through fiction and non-fiction.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Interesting content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Nicholas White has been the best professor I encountered during my four years at Duke—and I’ve had the privilege of learning from many exceptional ones. While C.S. Lewis’s writings would have likely impacted me regardless of the instructor, Professor White elevated the course to a whole other level, and heightened my view of my already excellent academic experience at Duke. He brings not only profound intellect but also a rare depth of character and integrity, as well as the indispensable traits of wit and humor. His commitment to his students is evident in the time he devoted to one-on-one tutorial feedback on our papers and two separate Flunches. I sincerely hope Duke chooses to hire Professor White; he would be an extraordinary addition to the university. I will remember this course for the rest of my life.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were very interesting to me as a Christian and someone who had read Narnia many times over. It was enlightening to hear about Lewis' takes on God as the great iconoclast or his debates on whether God was good when he was grieving for his wife. The fiction was also extremely stimulating, as if it was an onion with so many layers beneath that even a lifetime of study would not pierce through to the core. Regardless of the difficulties in understanding, especially The Abolition of Man, the course really made me think about religion and fiction in a way that I never would on my own, and those difficulties only pushed me to try to understand deeper.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Get ready to learn so much. I learned how to be a better student, person, and thinker. I have never had to be so confident in my opinions and ready to argue them against a far more knowledgable person, but get ready to learn how to be confident in your arguments and defend them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: First off, this is an amazing class and if you're interested in CS Lewis for his fictional or his theological works, I cannot recommend this class enough. This class does have a high and often dense reading workload but I never felt like we read anything that wasn't worth reading. The reading selection is very well thought out and clearly connects to themes of the class. I think the hardest thing about this course for me was the fact that I had an otherwise very heavy course load (I took 6 classes this semester) so I wasn't able to engage as deeply in the readings as I would have liked. This class is absolutely worth spending the time on but if you don't have the class, don't kid yourself into thinking you do. This may sound harsh but if you don't have time to make time, this class will be a waste of your time. BUT if you are interested in this class, it is 100% beyond a shadow of a doubt WORTH MAKING TIME FOR. I took this class my sophomore spring and so far, it is one of my absolute favorite classes at Duke (definitely top five and maybe even top three). Side note but this is may be the most well-structured class I have taken at Duke so far. Everything was incredibly and clearly well thought out. Never in this course did I feel like I was doing busy work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: "I would not recommend this course to future students. While visiting the pyramids was a highlight, the overall experience was stressful and lacked the immersive, enriching quality one would hope for in a study abroad program. The professor was not understanding of students’ well-being, often disregarding exhaustion, illness, or logistical delays, and dismissing concerns with comments like 'you're a Duke student.' His teaching style included frequent irrelevant rants and unsolicited political commentary, which made many students uncomfortable. Additionally, much of the course content felt repetitive and unimpactful — visiting similar sites repeatedly without meaningful academic engagement. Weekend trips were exhausting and rushed, leaving little time to actually take in the experiences. The professor was largely absent outside of class and trips, and offered little personal engagement with students.On top of this, there were unexpected out-of-pocket costs that added up quickly, even for group meals that were supposed to be included. Given the high program cost, this was frustrating. Assignment deadlines were rigid, regardless of student health or circumstances, and there was a clear lack of empathy when students were sick or overwhelmed.Honestly, there’s so much about this program that could be talked about for hours — from the disorganization to the exhausting schedule, to the uncomfortable moments with the professor. If I could do it over, I would choose a different study abroad program that better balances academic rigor with cultural immersion and student well-being. The photos might look nice, but they don’t reflect the reality of the experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - I wo;uld like to say my focus was primarily on themes of humanism, identity, and racial capital. Each of these themes are directly connected to one another and approach the idea of the black radical tradition in various ways. For humanism, we spent the course reading Fanon, Robinson, Wilderson and other black intellectual thinkers who are redefining what it means to be and exist outside the concept of being human. This directly leads to our understanding of how this would affect idenity, as if one is not even considered to be human or considered to be lesser than human, their would be a sort of inferiority complex or psychological notion of subjugation that would become instilled in a community. Thus, the ideas surrounding racial capital come into the foray, for in order to further advance the rather insatiable hunger of capitalism and its systems, a form of racial order or hierarchy only benefits profit and labor. This course helped me in connecting some of these ideas effectively and providing thoughtful analysis when bringing together these subjects.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the intention behind crafting an interdisciplinary classroom, made possible by crosslisting this course across many departments and opening it to UNC students. I loved studying these historic texts and secondary sources with students outside of my own program, which allowed for new insights and understandings that have shaped the way I approach work in my home discipline. Dr. Martin created a lot of pathways for us to engage with the material, and I appreciated the weekly message board assignment as it allowed for me to engage my classmates and begin a dialogue even before I entered the classroom. This was especially meaningful for a weekly seminar where I only see my classmates once a week, and want to make the most of the time together. Dr. Martin did a great job lightly facilitating the class, but otherwise emphasizing a student-led discussion of the materials. He never discouraged us from pressing a topic or conversation further, even if it didn't directly address the overall seminar topic, and these conversations always ended up being very rich and linking us back to the ideas and concerns that make us interested in studying Columbus in the first place.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. Professor Ara Wilson's concept of queer regionalism is especially insightful, as it negotiates the dominant Western queer studies with cultural contexts in East Asian society. 2. Professor Qiao's illustrations on the Homeowner Associations in China shows how grassroots organizations not only function hand in hand with the state power but also grant a degree of agency for ordinary people. 3. I've been intrigued by the approach that views Asia as a method instead of the object of study, which stresses cross-regional culture flow and Asia's cultural specificity as a whole.

response_text: 1. Professor Ara Wilson's concept of queer regionalism is especially insightful, as it negotiates the dominant Western queer studies with cultural contexts in East Asian society. 2. response_text: I developed a greater understanding for how to write in various academic settings. This class helped me both on the micro and macro level to elevate my academic style and prose. It is very beneficial for any young scholar to take and will increase the quality of your writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me more self-consciously analyze my own writing to better match my mode of argument with my goal. Overall, the class reinforced important elements of concision in scholarly writing (avoid nominalization and passive voice).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Generally speaking, I learned writing skills. I learned how to write (1) concisely, (2) in the various scholarly genres (e.g., encyclopedia entries, opinions pieces, book reviews), and (3) with clarity and structure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New perspectives on academic writing, concrete tools and methods for improving my writing, and how to conduct a class on such a technical topic in a way that is fun and productive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very hands-on in his academic approach. He taught us by having us do outside research, constant writing, and peer evaluating. I would keep everything he included for future courses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading foundational philosophical texts from the centers and margins really transform my mindset, helps me academically, and religious thoughts. The reading list is both wide in scope and generatively constructed. Ideas and resonance between old european canon and african american studies' texts are outstandingly good.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned more about existentialism and nihilism. Those were concepts I wasn't familiar with coming into the course. I appreciated the opportunity to challenge the traditional existentialist canon that centers white men. As a non-white student this was helpful in getting and keeping me engaged in the course. I really appreciated the was that Professor Winters paired traditional existential readings with those that engaged gender, race, and class in different ways. I was also encouraged to think about the ways other scholars engage with themes from existentialism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sitting in circle. Giving ample room for first impression of the texts. Introducing each text before the text is assigned (a week before) and when discussion about to start (on the week).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the wide variety of authors we read from a number of different disciplines that all wrote on existentialism. That, along with the variety of disciplines being studied in the class made the course very interesting and covered a wide breadth of material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend a class with Professor Winters. He integrates well Black Studies, religious studies, and philosophy. He brought a unique perspective to Religion, Existentialism, and Nihilism that helps to provide insight into how different philosophical beliefs can play out in the everyday as well as the ways that identity and context shape how we engage with certain themes and ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how approach the research process and how to engage with primary sources not just as text but as whole historical objects to be explored. This course allowed me to then apply these research methods to a primary source through the manuscript project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Broader knowledge of the field of material studies in general and Christian manuscript cultures in particular. Methods of analyzing a manuscript, from production to provenance. Insights into the scholarly methodologies at play in the field, and an idea of what kind of scholarship is being done today. Thinking more critically about how to analyze a piece of scholarship concerning manuscript cultures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the main themes of this class was exploring the ethics behind manuscript collections and acquisitions. In addition, we gained competency in accessing rare manuscripts from the Rubenstein collection and how to prepare for a visit effectively. Finally, I learned to think critically of manuscripts are material objects in their own right with stories to tell, rather than as mere repositories of disembodied text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A much more comprehensive understanding of manuscript studies, and all that entails, which I previously had no interaction with

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to use collections
How to read miniscule
How to begin to study a manuscript!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to conduct provenance research, how to conduct provenience research, and how to trace textual transmission.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course served as an introduction to the field of manuscript studies and to Duke's Rubenstein collection. I felt that I learned about the field's evolution as well as its current state. Through this course, I have begun to think about historical texts as material objects as well as texts. The opportunity to consider our chosen manuscripts from the angles of content, provenience and provenance helped develop this skill.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a working knowledge of the basics of manuscript studies, an orientation to the use of manuscripts for my further research on various ancient texts, and the ethical stakes of modern provenance research.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the discussion leaders and how they and Dr. Knust would provide handouts for each week. It really helped me to focus during class and I think helped the class discussion stay on track while also allowing for tangents when they organically occurred from the discussion. I also think being assigned a manuscript for the whole semester is a brilliant idea and I really enjoyed all aspects of that project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found the student-led seminars very helpful both from the perspective of running them and receiving them. I also found the work of analyzing a manuscript in the Rubenstein collection deeply engaging and very exciting--an excellent opportunity to put into practice the theory being discussed in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. sociology and methods

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I have learnt Confucianism in East Asia, which I had no relative knowledge before. This knowledge on East Asian Confucianism provides with inspiration on my own study.
2. Since students need to upload memos on the readings each week, it improves my writing skills and helps me to remember the topics of each class in the end of the semester.
3. The professor highly recommends the Duke Library website, and I find it truly useful for academic research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have acquired more knowledge of a vital component chaining the Asian history which may be taken for granted thus lack reflective illustrations in many studies. And I learned much about the idea of sacredness and spirits, and more importantly how to think and study them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Transnational spreading of Confucianism, ethnographical methodologies, religious factors and evaluations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've read about various insightful interpretations of Confucian classics and the relationship between traditional Confucian values and contemporary societies. Specifically, I'm especially impressed by the perspective of viewing Confucianism as a religion, which entails a very novel and persuasive definition of the term religion itself. I've also encountered many Confucian ritual practices which I've been familiar with in my past life, and gained completely new understandings of these rituals, especially ancestral worships. Third, I've been intrigued by a recent reading material discussing the "as-if" world created by ritual practices, with an emphasis on the gap between the Confucian ideal and the reality.
